questions.text: Which of the following fits into the criteria of severe variable deceleration, variations less than: (AIIMS NOV 2017)

options.label: A
options.text: 90 beats per minute lasting for 60 seconds

options.label: B
options.text: 80 beats per minute lasting for 60 seconds

options.label: C
options.text: 100 beats per minute lasting for 60 seconds

options.label: D
options.text: 70 beats per minute lasting for 60 seconds

questions.correct_answer: D. 70 beats per minute lasting for 60 seconds
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) 70 beats per minute lasting for 60 seconds

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Severe variable decelerations are defined by a fetal heart rate dropping to less than 70 beats per minute for at least 60 seconds, typically due to umbilical cord compression.

questions.text: Which of the following is the correct sign indicating adequate growth in an infant with a birth weight of 3 kg? (NEET PG 2023)

options.label: A
options.text: Increase in length of 25 cm in the first year

options.label: B
options.text: Weight gain of 300 grams per month till 1 year

options.label: C
options.text: Anterior fontanelle closure by 6 months of age

options.label: D
options.text: Weight under 75th percentile and height under 25th percentile

questions.correct_answer: A. Increase in length of 25 cm in the first year
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Increase in length of 25 cm in the first year

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ An increase in length of 25 cm in the first year is a key indicator of adequate growth in infants.

questions.text: Which of the following is the best indicator of some dehydration in SAM? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.correct_answer: C. Urine output, Thirst & oral mucosa
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Urine output, Thirst & oral mucosa

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In SAM children, the best indicators of dehydration are urine output, the dryness of the oral mucosa and the child's thirst.

questions.text: Identify the disease shown in the karyotype: (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Cri-du-chat syndrome

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Cri-du-chat syndrome is identified by a partial deletion on the short arm of chromosome 5, leading to distinctive clinical features such as a cat-like cry, microcephaly, and intellectual disability.

questions.text: A 2-month-old infant born to an HIV-positive mother presents with recurrent diarrhea. What is the next best step? (NEET PG 2022)

options.label: A
options.text: Test stool for giardia and give antibiotics

options.label: B
options.text: Dried spot sample for HIV DNA PCR

questions.correct_answer: B. Dried spot sample for HIV DNA PCR
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Dried spot sample for HIV DNA PCR

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The next best step in diagnosing HIV in infants born to HIV-positive mothers is to perform an HIV DNA PCR test using a dried blood spot sample.

questions.text: In which of the following conditions is the appearance of enlarged calves, as shown in the image, typically seen in a child? (AIIMS NOV 2016)
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The image shows enlargement of the calves (pseudohypertrophy) along with wasting of thigh muscles, which are classic features of Duchenne muscular dystrophy (DMD). This condition is the most common form of muscular dystrophy. The pseudohypertrophy is caused by hypertrophy of some muscle fibers, infiltration of muscle by fat, and proliferation of collagen. DMD is an X-linked recessive disorder caused by a mutation in the gene responsible for producing dystrophin.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Spinal muscular atrophy - This condition primarily involves muscle weakness and atrophy but does not typically present with calf pseudohypertrophy.
  • • Option A. Spinal muscular atrophy
  • • Option B. Myopathy - General term for muscle disease; specific types may present with muscle weakness but not necessarily with calf pseudohypertrophy.
  • • Option B. Myopathy
  • • Option D. Peripheral neuropathy - This condition involves damage to peripheral nerves, leading to muscle weakness and atrophy but not pseudohypertrophy.
  • • Option D. Peripheral neuropathy

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Enlargement of the calves, known as pseudohypertrophy, along with muscle wasting, is a classic feature of Duchenne muscular dystrophy

questions.text: Which one among the following has the lowest risk of perinatal transmission? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Rubella

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Rubella has the lowest risk of perinatal transmission among the options listed, though it can still cause serious fetal complications if transmitted during pregnancy.

questions.text: Choose the correct order of suctioning during neonatal resuscitation? (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Mouth-nose

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ During neonatal resuscitation, the mouth should be suctioned before the nose to minimize the risk of aspiration and ensure a clear airway for effective ventilation.

questions.text: The following finding can be seen in: (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Parvovirus B19 infection

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Recognize the causative agent of the 5th disease (erythema infectiosum) as Parvovirus B19. Understand the clinical manifestations of the 5th disease, including the characteristic "slapped-cheek" rash, and differentiate it from other childhood viral infections such as HFMD and conditions like Kawasaki disease and molluscum contagiosum.

questions.text: All the following PFT findings in a child are suggestive of asthma except? ( INICET MAY 2020)

options.label: A
options.text: Increase in FEV1> 15% after salbutamol inhalation

questions.correct_answer: C. Day- night variation of FEV1 > 15%
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Day- night variation of FEV1 > 15%

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ An increase in FEV1 > 15% after bronchodilator use and a FEV1/FVC ratio < 80% are key PFT findings suggestive of asthma.

questions.text: A 9-year-old boy has swelling of knee joints and non-blanching rashes as seen in the picture. Urine exam reveals haematuria +++ and proteinuria +. Platelet levels are normal. What is the probable diagnosis? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Henoch Schonlein purpura (HSP)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Henoch-Schönlein purpura (HSP) is characterized by a purpuric rash, arthritis, abdominal pain, and renal complications such as hematuria and proteinuria, typically following the rash development.

questions.text: A 9-year-old child with thalassemia is undergoing regular blood transfusions every few weeks. Due to the frequent transfusions, there is concern about the risk of iron overload, which can damage vital organs such as the liver, heart, and endocrine glands. To assess the iron levels in the body, the healthcare provider is planning to conduct appropriate tests. What is the best method to detect iron overload in this child?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Children with thalassemia who undergo multiple blood transfusions are at significant risk of iron overload, which can lead to damage in the liver, heart, and endocrine glands. Monitoring liver iron concentration is the best method to assess iron overload because it directly indicates total body iron stores.
  • • Liver Iron Concentration Measurement:
  • • Liver Iron Concentration Measurement:
  • • Liver Biopsy: An invasive method that measures iron content directly in liver tissue. While it is accurate, it carries risks such as bleeding and discomfort, making it less suitable for regular monitoring. T2 MRI of the Liver: A non-invasive, preferred method for assessing liver iron concentration. This imaging technique is reliable, safe, and accurate for ongoing monitoring of iron levels without the risks associated with liver biopsy. T2 MRI is often used in clinical practice due to its ability to provide detailed measurements of liver iron, guiding management and treatment.
  • • Liver Biopsy: An invasive method that measures iron content directly in liver tissue. While it is accurate, it carries risks such as bleeding and discomfort, making it less suitable for regular monitoring.
  • • Liver Biopsy:
  • • T2 MRI of the Liver: A non-invasive, preferred method for assessing liver iron concentration. This imaging technique is reliable, safe, and accurate for ongoing monitoring of iron levels without the risks associated with liver biopsy. T2 MRI is often used in clinical practice due to its ability to provide detailed measurements of liver iron, guiding management and treatment.
  • • T2 MRI of the Liver:
  • • Other Relevant Tests for Monitoring Iron Overload:
  • • Other Relevant Tests for Monitoring Iron Overload:
  • • Serum Ferritin Levels: Can be used every three months to monitor iron levels but is not as specific or reliable as liver iron concentration measurements because it can be influenced by inflammation and other factors. T2 MRI of the Heart: This test measures cardiac iron levels but is not the primary method for assessing overall iron overload. Echocardiography: Primarily used to assess heart function and detect complications due to iron overload but does not measure iron directly.
  • • Serum Ferritin Levels: Can be used every three months to monitor iron levels but is not as specific or reliable as liver iron concentration measurements because it can be influenced by inflammation and other factors.
  • • Serum Ferritin Levels:
  • • T2 MRI of the Heart: This test measures cardiac iron levels but is not the primary method for assessing overall iron overload.
  • • T2 MRI of the Heart:
  • • Echocardiography: Primarily used to assess heart function and detect complications due to iron overload but does not measure iron directly.
  • • Echocardiography:
  • • Management of Iron Overload:
  • • Management of Iron Overload:
  • • Chelation Therapy: Essential for removing excess iron from the body. Common agents include deferoxamine (administered intravenously or subcutaneously), deferasirox, and deferiprone (both oral medications), which help prevent organ damage by binding excess iron for excretion.
  • • Chelation Therapy:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Liver iron concentration measurement, especially through T2 MRI, is the best method to detect iron overload in children with thalassemia undergoing frequent blood transfusions. It accurately reflects total body iron stores, allowing for effective monitoring and management of iron levels to prevent organ damage.

questions.text: Adrenocorticotropic hormone is the drug of choice in which of the following conditions? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) West syndrome

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH) is the drug of choice in West syndrome.

questions.text: Which pattern of inheritance does the pedigree chart denote? (AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Autosomal-recessive disorder

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Autosomal-recessive disorders are typically characterized by a horizontal pattern of inheritance, where the disorder appears in siblings of the same generation but may skip generations, with unaffected parents often being carriers.

questions.text: A 9-month-old boy presents with progressive pallor and abdominal distension. The peripheral smear done is as shown below, and the Mentzer index was found to be less than 13. What are the investigations to be done in this patient? (INICET NOV 2022) High-performance liquid chromatography (HPLC) PT and APTT Bone marrow Peripheral blood smear
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) 1 and 4

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In a child suspected of having thalassemia, High-performance liquid chromatography (HPLC) and a peripheral blood smear are key investigations for diagnosis.

questions.text: During the anthropometric evaluation, the height for age of a child is < - 2D. This is most likely due to? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Chronic malnutrition

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Height for age < -2SD is indicative of chronic malnutrition, also known as stunting, which results from prolonged inadequate nutrition, particularly during the critical early years of a child's life.

questions.text: Which of the following is seen in physiological jaundice? ( INICET MAY 2021)

options.label: A
options.text: Increased indirect bilirubin, increased urobilinogen, absent bilirubin in urine

options.label: B
options.text: Increased indirect bilirubin, absent urobilinogen, absent bilirubin in urine

options.label: C
options.text: Increased direct bilirubin, increased urobilinogen, absent bilirubin in urine

options.label: D
options.text: Increased direct bilirubin, absent urobilinogen, absent bilirubin in urine

questions.correct_answer: A. Increased indirect bilirubin, increased urobilinogen, absent bilirubin in urine
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Increased indirect bilirubin, increased urobilinogen, absent bilirubin in urine

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Physiological jaundice is characterized by increased indirect bilirubin, increased urobilinogen, and the absence of bilirubin in the urine.

questions.text: Sign of effective neonatal resuscitation is: (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Increased heart rate

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The best indicator of successful newborn resuscitation is a rise in heart rate.

questions.text: A neonate is found to have increased irritability, poor feeding, and 2 episodes of seizures. Lumbar puncture was done and the findings were suggestive of meningitis. What is the most likely causative organism? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Streptococcus agalactiae

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Group B Streptococcus (Streptococcus agalactiae) is the most common cause of neonatal meningitis and sepsis, and early recognition and treatment are critical for reducing morbidity and mortality.

questions.text: The following device shown attached to the baby is used in all except: (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Measure central cyanosis.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A pulse oximeter is useful in various neonatal and resuscitation settings to monitor oxygen saturation and heart rate, but it is not reliable for detecting central cyanosis.

questions.text: A 7-year-old girl is brought to the clinic by her parents due to continuous dribbling of urine since birth. Despite this, she can void normally when using the toilet. Her parents report that she has never been completely dry, and this has significantly impacted her daily activities. There is no history of urinary tract infections, recent trauma, or surgeries. Physical examination reveals normal external genitalia with no signs of infection or abnormalities. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The clinical presentation of continuous dribbling of urine from birth despite normal voiding suggests an ectopic ureter. An ectopic ureter is a congenital anomaly resulting from improper positioning of the ureter during fetal development. In females, the ectopic ureter often drains outside the bladder, commonly inserting into the vagina or distal urethra, leading to persistent urinary incontinence.
  • • Ectopic Ureter: Typically presents with continuous urine leakage because the ureter bypasses the normal continence mechanisms of the bladder.
  • • Ectopic Ureter:
  • • This condition often goes undetected until later in childhood, as affected individuals can still void normally with the normally positioned ureter.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A) Vesicoureteral reflux: This condition involves the backward flow of urine from the bladder into the ureters, which can lead to recurrent urinary tract infections. It does not typically cause continuous urine dribbling.
  • • Option
  • • A) Vesicoureteral reflux:
  • • Option B) Urinary tract infection: UTIs present with symptoms such as dysuria, frequency, and urgency, but they do not cause continuous dribbling since birth.
  • • Option
  • • B) Urinary tract infection:
  • • Option D) Bladder exstrophy: A severe congenital condition where the bladder is exposed outside the body, usually diagnosed at birth. It presents with visible bladder abnormalities, which are not seen in this case.
  • • Option
  • • D) Bladder exstrophy:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ An ectopic ureter should be suspected in a young female presenting with continuous urinary dribbling since birth despite normal voiding. It results from an abnormal ureteral insertion, often requiring imaging studies for diagnosis and surgical intervention for correction.

questions.text: Identify the vitamin which when deficient can lead to neonatal seizures? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Pyridoxine

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Pyridoxine deficiency can cause refractory seizures in neonates, and recognizing this condition is crucial because these seizures can be rapidly treated with pyridoxine supplementation.

questions.text: A 3-year-old male has the following buccal mucosa finding. After three days, he presents to your OPD with a rash. What is your diagnosis? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Measles

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Measles is characterized by the presence of Koplik spots on the buccal mucosa followed by a widespread rash, starting from the face and neck.

questions.text: The following image depicts which of the following diseases? ( AIIMS Nov 2017)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Scabies

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The presence of linear tunnel like lesions called as burrows in the stratum corneum of the skin, as depicted in the image, is a hallmark sign of scabie s, distinguishing it from other skin conditions like ichthyosis, contact dermatitis, and urticaria.
  • ➤ linear tunnel like
  • ➤ burrows
  • ➤ corneum
  • ➤ hallmark sign
  • ➤ scabie
  • ➤ Ref - Rooks textbook of dermatology- 9 th Edition Chapter 34 page no 34.39-34.47
  • ➤ Ref - Rooks textbook of dermatology- 9 th Edition Chapter 34 page no 34.39-34.47
  • ➤ Fitzpatrick’s dermatology 9 th edition page no: 3274
  • ➤ Fitzpatrick’s dermatology 9 th edition page no: 3274

questions.text: A young male came to the hospital with a clean-cut wound without any bleeding. The patient received a full course of tetanus vaccination 10 years ago. What is the best management for this patient?(NEET PG 2023)

options.label: A
options.text: Human tetanus immunoglobulin and full course of vaccine

questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Single-dose tetanus toxoid

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Management of Tetanus-Prone Wounds:
  • ➤ Management of Tetanus-Prone Wounds:
  • ➤ CC = Complete course; TIG = Tetanus Immunoglobulin

questions.text: Which of the following is not a growth factor promoting proto-oncogene? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) TGF-beta

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ TGF-beta is not a growth factor that promotes proto-oncogenes; instead, it is involved in down-regulating the inflammatory response and facilitating wound healing.

questions.text: The drug of choice for insomnia in blind people is? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Tasimelteon

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Tasimelteon is the drug of choice for treating insomnia in blind individuals due to its effectiveness in regulating the sleep-wake cycle by acting as a melatonin receptor agonist, particularly in those with Non-24-Hour Sleep-Wake Disorder.

questions.text: A 56-year-old man presents with dragging pain in the abdomen. On examination, there is massive splenomegaly. Peripheral smear shows leukocytosis with increased myelocytes, metamyelocytes and basophils. Which of the following translocation is seen in this condition? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) t (9:22)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The translocation t(9;22) is characteristic of chronic myeloid leukemia (CML) and results in the formation of the Philadelphia chromosome, which produces the BCR-ABL fusion gene responsible for the disease's pathogenesis.

questions.text: A neonate presents with cicatrizing skin lesions all over the body and limb hypoplasia. An MRI of the brain shows diffuse cerebral atrophy, and an ophthalmologic evaluation reveals chorioretinitis. Which test is most likely to be positive in this patient? (AIIMS NOV 2016)
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The clinical presentation of cicatrizing skin lesions, limb hypoplasia, cerebral atrophy, and chorioretinitis suggests congenital varicella syndrome. This condition is caused by an intrauterine infection with the varicella-zoster virus (VZV). Detection of anti-VZV antibodies in the patient would confirm this diagnosis.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Anti-HCMV antibodies - These are associated with congenital cytomegalovirus infection, which presents differently.
  • • Option A. Anti-HCMV antibodies
  • • Option B. Anti-toxoplasma antibodies - These are associated with congenital toxoplasmosis, characterized by different clinical features.
  • • Option B. Anti-toxoplasma antibodies
  • • Option D. Anti-rubella antibody - These are associated with congenital rubella syndrome, which also presents with different symptoms.
  • • Option D. Anti-rubella antibody

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Congenital varicella syndrome can be diagnosed by the presence of anti-VZV antibodies, which correlate with characteristic features such as cicatrizing skin lesions, limb hypoplasia, cerebral atrophy, and chorioretinitis.

questions.text: During her pregnancy, the lady regularly cleans her cat's litter to prevent toxoplasma infection. What is the specific infective stage of this organism found in the cat feces? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Oocysts

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The specific infective stage of Toxoplasma gondii found in cat feces is the oocyst, which poses a risk of infection if ingested.

questions.text: A patient with a history of a backache for 10 days, has now presented with difficulty in micturition and defecation. There was no history of a cough or fever previously. What is the diagnosis? (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Cauda-Equina syndrome

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Cauda Equina Syndrome presents with acute lower back pain and severe disturbances in bladder and bowel control due to compression of the nerve roots in the lumbar and sacral areas, requiring urgent medical attention to prevent permanent damage.

References:

  • ↳ Reference - Harrison/Neurology/Diseases of spinal Cord/Chap 442

questions.text: Enzyme deficient in pompe’s disease is: (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Alpha 1, 4 glucosidase

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Understand the enzymatic basis of Pompe's disease, recognizing that it is caused by a deficiency of alpha-1,4-glucosidase (acid maltase). Be aware of the clinical manifestations and biochemical abnormalities associated with Pompe's disease, which is characterized by the accumulation of glycogen in various tissues, particularly in muscles.

questions.text: Which vaccine among the options is not recommended for use during pregnancy? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Varicella

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 2-year-old child is brought to the clinic with a painful and growing swelling on the parietal region of the head. The parents report that the child had a fall one year ago, resulting in a parietal bone fracture. Since then, they have noticed that the swelling has progressively increased in size. The child has not had any recent trauma, and there are no signs of fever or infection. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The condition described is consistent with a growing fracture , also known as a traumatic leptomeningeal cyst or encephalocele cyst . Growing fractures occur when a skull fracture with an associated dural tear fails to heal properly, leading to progressive enlargement due to herniation of brain tissue, cerebrospinal fluid, or a leptomeningeal cyst.
  • • growing fracture
  • • leptomeningeal cyst or encephalocele cyst
  • • Mechanism of Growing Fracture:
  • • Mechanism of Growing Fracture:
  • • Skull fractures with dural tears may not heal correctly, allowing brain tissue, dilated ventricles, or a leptomeningeal cyst to herniate through the defect. This condition is known as a growing skull fracture.
  • • Clinical Features:
  • • Clinical Features:
  • • Commonly affects children younger than 3 years old.
  • • The condition is usually detected within a year of an acute head injury, presenting as localized swelling or a palpable skull defect that increases in size over time.
  • • If left untreated, the condition can present later with symptoms such as headaches, seizures, or neurological deficits.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A) Subdural hematoma: Typically presents with acute neurological symptoms and is not characterized by progressive swelling over time.
  • • Option
  • • A) Subdural hematoma:
  • • Option B) Epidermoid cyst: A benign, slow-growing cyst that does not typically present with a history of head trauma or progressive skull enlargement.
  • • Option
  • • B) Epidermoid cyst:
  • • Option D) Scalp abscess: Usually associated with infection, pain, and tenderness, and would not be related to a history of previous skull fracture.
  • • Option
  • • D) Scalp abscess:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Growing fractures should be suspected in young children presenting with a progressively enlarging swelling at the site of a previous skull fracture. Early diagnosis and management are essential to prevent long-term neurological complications such as seizures and other deficits.

questions.text: Identify the correct match, regarding the drug and its adverse effect? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D. Verapamil – constipation

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Verapamil, a non-dihydropyridine calcium channel blocker, is associated with constipation as a common adverse effect. Other drugs and their incorrect matches in this context include hydralazine (which can cause drug-induced lupus), atenolol (which does not cause hemolytic anemia), and aliskiren (which can cause hyperkalemia, not hypokalemia).

questions.text: Which of the following is normally seen in lumbar spine? ( AIIMS Nov 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Lordosis

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Lordosis refers to the inward (anterior) curvature of the spine. It's the normal anatomical curvature seen in the lumbar (lower back) and cervical (neck) regions. In the lumbar region, lordosis allows for an upright posture and helps to evenly distribute the body's weight and the forces exerted on the spine. While a certain degree of lumbar lordosis is normal and healthy, excessive lordosis (often called "swayback") can lead to pain and other issues.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Scoliosis: Scoliosis refers to a lateral (side-to-side) curvature of the spine. While any part of the spine can be affected, scoliosis most commonly develops in the thoracic (upper/mid back) and/or lumbar (lower back) regions. It's important to note that while scoliosis can affect the lumbar spine, it is not the normal anatomical curvature for that region. Instead, it's a pathological condition which can be idiopathic (most common, especially in adolescents), congenital, or secondary to other conditions.
  • • Option A. Scoliosis:
  • • Option B. Kyphosis: Kyphosis describes a forward (anterior) rounding or curvature of the spine, producing a "hunchback" appearance. The normal anatomical region that displays kyphosis is the thoracic spine (upper/mid back). When present in the lumbar spine, it is considered pathological and is usually secondary to conditions like osteoporosis (which causes compression fractures), degenerative diseases, or other spine disorders.
  • • Option B. Kyphosis:
  • • Option D. Recurvatum: Recurvatum typically refers to a backward bending or hyperextension of a joint. While this term can be applied to various joints in the body, it's most commonly associated with the knee joint, where the knee bends backward excessively. It doesn't directly pertain to the natural anatomical curvatures of the spine.
  • • Option D. Recurvatum:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In adults,
  • ➤ The cervical curve is a lordosis (convex forwards), The thoracic curve is a kyphosis (convex dorsally), The lumbar curve is also a lordosis, The pelvic curve is concave anteroinferiorly.
  • ➤ The cervical curve is a lordosis (convex forwards),
  • ➤ The thoracic curve is a kyphosis (convex dorsally),
  • ➤ The lumbar curve is also a lordosis,
  • ➤ The pelvic curve is concave anteroinferiorly.

questions.text: Which of the following statements are true regarding cytomegalovirus (CMV) infection? (INICET NOV 2022) Neonates who are asymptomatic at birth have a lesser risk of later sequelae. 20-40% are symptomatic at birth. In developing countries, the rate of transmission of CMV infection to the infant is more common from primary maternal infection than reactivation. Diagnosis by urine specimen at 4 weeks of age
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) 1, 3

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Neonates who are asymptomatic at birth from congenital CMV infection have a lower risk of long-term sequelae, and transmission is more common from primary maternal infection than from reactivation, especially in developing countries.

questions.text: A 25-year primigravida is on indomethacin (25mg TDS) for polyhydramnios till 35 weeks. What abnormality can the fetus have if she goes into labor now? (NEET PG 2021)

options.label: C
options.text: Premature closure of the ductus arteriosus

options.label: D
options.text: Premature closure of the ductus venosus

questions.correct_answer: C. Premature closure of the ductus arteriosus
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Premature closure of the ductus arteriosus

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Indomethacin and Fetal Effects:
  • • Indomethacin and Fetal Effects:
  • • Indomethacin is a non-selective cyclo-oxygenase inhibitor used in obstetrics primarily for two indications: Polyhydramnios: To reduce the excessive amniotic fluid. Tocolytic in preterm labor: To delay preterm labor. Mechanism: Indomethacin works by inhibiting the production of prostaglandins, which are important for maintaining the patency of the ductus arteriosus in the fetus. Risks: When used beyond 32 weeks of gestation, indomethacin can cause premature closure of the ductus arteriosus , leading to complications such as: Pulmonary hypertension Right ventricular hypertrophy Heart failure
  • • Indomethacin is a non-selective cyclo-oxygenase inhibitor used in obstetrics primarily for two indications: Polyhydramnios: To reduce the excessive amniotic fluid. Tocolytic in preterm labor: To delay preterm labor.
  • • Indomethacin
  • • Polyhydramnios: To reduce the excessive amniotic fluid. Tocolytic in preterm labor: To delay preterm labor.
  • • Polyhydramnios: To reduce the excessive amniotic fluid.
  • • Polyhydramnios:
  • • Tocolytic in preterm labor: To delay preterm labor.
  • • Tocolytic in preterm labor:
  • • Mechanism: Indomethacin works by inhibiting the production of prostaglandins, which are important for maintaining the patency of the ductus arteriosus in the fetus.
  • • Mechanism:
  • • Risks: When used beyond 32 weeks of gestation, indomethacin can cause premature closure of the ductus arteriosus , leading to complications such as: Pulmonary hypertension Right ventricular hypertrophy Heart failure
  • • Risks:
  • • premature closure of the ductus arteriosus
  • • Pulmonary hypertension Right ventricular hypertrophy Heart failure
  • • Pulmonary hypertension
  • • Right ventricular hypertrophy
  • • Heart failure
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Flap closure of foramen ovale: The foramen ovale normally closes soon after birth when the pressure in the left atrium exceeds the pressure in the right atrium. Indomethacin does not affect the closure of the foramen ovale.
  • • Option A. Flap closure of foramen ovale:
  • • Option B. Patent ductus arteriosus: Patent ductus arteriosus (PDA) is a condition where the ductus arteriosus remains open after birth. Indomethacin is actually used to treat PDA by promoting its closure, not causing it.
  • • Option B. Patent ductus arteriosus:
  • • Option D. Premature closure of the ductus venosus: The ductus venosus allows oxygenated blood from the umbilical vein to bypass the liver and flow directly into the inferior vena cava. Indomethacin does not influence the closure of the ductus venosus.
  • • Option D. Premature closure of the ductus venosus:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Indomethacin can cause premature closure of the ductus arteriosus if used beyond 32 weeks of gestation.
  • ➤ Ref: Page 679, Williams Obstetrics 26 th edition
  • ➤ Ref: Page 679, Williams Obstetrics 26 th edition

questions.text: A 65-year-old male patient with chronic fatigue and lymphadenopathy presents to the outpatient department. His peripheral smear shows the presence of smudge cells. Which of the following additional investigations will you do to arrive at a diagnosis? ( AIIMS NOV 2021)

  • ➤ Ref: Robins Pathologic basis of disease 8 th edition pg 1114

questions.text: A 5-year-old child with steroid-dependent nephrotic syndrome is brought to the outpatient department for routine vaccination. The child has been on long-term corticosteroid therapy and was recently started on cyclosporine due to frequent relapses. The parents are worried about the safety of vaccinations, given the child’s immunosuppressive medications. What is the most appropriate recommendation regarding vaccinations for this child?

options.label: A
options.text: Live virus vaccines are safe and should be administered without restrictions.

options.label: B
options.text: All killed vaccines can be given, but live virus vaccines should be administered cautiously.

options.label: C
options.text: Live vaccines are recommended for children on corticosteroid-sparing drugs like cyclophosphamide.

options.label: D
options.text: Household contacts should avoid live vaccines to reduce the risk of illness transmission to the child.

questions.correct_answer: B. All killed vaccines can be given, but live virus vaccines should be administered cautiously.
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Children with steroid-dependent nephrotic syndrome on corticosteroid and immunosuppressive therapy require careful consideration when it comes to vaccinations:
  • • Killed Vaccines: All killed vaccines are safe for children receiving corticosteroids or other immunosuppressive agents and can be administered without restrictions. Live Virus Vaccines: These vaccines should be administered cautiously, particularly in children on corticosteroids. Live vaccines are generally safe for children receiving less than 1 mg/kg of prednisone per day or 2 mg/kg every other day. However, live vaccines are not recommended for children on corticosteroid-sparing drugs such as cyclophosphamide, cyclosporine, and similar agents due to the increased risk of severe infection. Prevention of Disease Transmission: Vaccination of healthy household contacts with live vaccines is important to reduce the risk of transmitting infections to the immunosuppressed child. To minimize risk, direct contact with the respiratory and gastrointestinal secretions of vaccinated individuals should be avoided for 3 to 6 weeks following vaccination. Management of Steroid-Dependent Nephrotic Syndrome: The most common cause of nephrotic syndrome in children is minimal change disease, which typically presents between ages 2 and 6 years. It is treated initially with corticosteroids. For frequent relapses or steroid toxicity, alternative therapies such as Cyclophosphamide, Calcineurin inhibitors (Cyclosporine, Tacrolimus), Mycophenolate, Levamisole, and Rituximab are used.
  • • Killed Vaccines: All killed vaccines are safe for children receiving corticosteroids or other immunosuppressive agents and can be administered without restrictions.
  • • Killed Vaccines:
  • • Live Virus Vaccines: These vaccines should be administered cautiously, particularly in children on corticosteroids. Live vaccines are generally safe for children receiving less than 1 mg/kg of prednisone per day or 2 mg/kg every other day. However, live vaccines are not recommended for children on corticosteroid-sparing drugs such as cyclophosphamide, cyclosporine, and similar agents due to the increased risk of severe infection.
  • • Live Virus Vaccines:
  • • Live vaccines are generally safe for children receiving less than 1 mg/kg of prednisone per day or 2 mg/kg every other day.
  • • Prevention of Disease Transmission: Vaccination of healthy household contacts with live vaccines is important to reduce the risk of transmitting infections to the immunosuppressed child. To minimize risk, direct contact with the respiratory and gastrointestinal secretions of vaccinated individuals should be avoided for 3 to 6 weeks following vaccination.
  • • Prevention of Disease Transmission:
  • • Management of Steroid-Dependent Nephrotic Syndrome: The most common cause of nephrotic syndrome in children is minimal change disease, which typically presents between ages 2 and 6 years. It is treated initially with corticosteroids. For frequent relapses or steroid toxicity, alternative therapies such as Cyclophosphamide, Calcineurin inhibitors (Cyclosporine, Tacrolimus), Mycophenolate, Levamisole, and Rituximab are used.
  • • Management of Steroid-Dependent Nephrotic Syndrome:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A) Live virus vaccines are safe and should be administered without restrictions: This is incorrect as live vaccines pose a risk in immunosuppressed children and should be given with caution.
  • • Option
  • • A) Live virus vaccines are safe and should be administered without restrictions:
  • • Option C) Live vaccines are recommended for children on corticosteroid-sparing drugs like cyclophosphamide: Incorrect, as live vaccines are contraindicated in those on corticosteroid-sparing agents due to the risk of severe infection.
  • • Option
  • • C) Live vaccines are recommended for children on corticosteroid-sparing drugs like cyclophosphamide:
  • • Option D) Household contacts should avoid live vaccines to reduce the risk of illness transmission to the child: Incorrect, as vaccinating household contacts with live vaccines helps protect the immunosuppressed child by preventing disease transmission.
  • • Option
  • • D) Household contacts should avoid live vaccines to reduce the risk of illness transmission to the child:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In children with steroid-dependent nephrotic syndrome, all killed vaccines can be given safely, while live virus vaccines should be used cautiously based on the child’s specific treatment regimen. Vaccination of household contacts with live vaccines is crucial to prevent the spread of infections to immunosuppressed children.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male presented with tachypnea and mental confusion. His blood sugar is 350 mg/dL, pH - 7.2, HCO3- 10 mEq/L, pCO2 – 25 mmHg. What is the metabolic abnormality? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Metabolic acidosis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In the presence of high blood sugar and the reported ABG values, metabolic acidosis, particularly diabetic ketoacidosis, should be considered. This condition requires prompt recognition and management, typically involving fluid resuscitation, insulin therapy, and electrolyte management to reverse the ketosis and acidosis.

questions.text: Which of the following is a suicide inhibitor? (INICET May 2024) Nor-ethindrone Ritonavir Spironolactone Benzbromarone
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) 1, 2 and 3

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Suicide inhibitors, also known as mechanism-based inhibitors, irreversibly bind to and permanently inactivate their target enzymes. This type of inhibition is significant because the enzyme activity cannot be restored unless new enzymes are synthesized by the body.
  • ➤ Mnemonic to Remember Important Suicide Inhibitors:
  • ➤ Mnemonic to Remember Important Suicide Inhibitors:
  • ➤ “Every Nurse Sees The Clot Results Promptly”
  • ➤ “Every Nurse Sees The Clot Results Promptly”
  • ➤ E : Ethinyl estradiol N : Norethindrone S : Spironolactone T : Ticlopidine C : Clopidogrel R : Ritonavir P : Propylthiouracil
  • ➤ E : Ethinyl estradiol
  • ➤ E
  • ➤ N : Norethindrone
  • ➤ N
  • ➤ S : Spironolactone
  • ➤ S
  • ➤ T : Ticlopidine
  • ➤ T
  • ➤ C : Clopidogrel
  • ➤ C
  • ➤ R : Ritonavir
  • ➤ R
  • ➤ P : Propylthiouracil
  • ➤ P

questions.text: A 4-day old baby is active and feeding well. He has a bilirubin level of 8 mg/dl. What is the next step in the management of the baby? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Continue breastfeeding.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In cases of physiological jaundice with mild to moderate bilirubin levels and a well-feeding, active infant, the appropriate management is to continue breastfeeding without additional interventions.

questions.text: What are the tactile hallucinations observed in instances of prolonged cocaine intoxication? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.explanation: Ans. B) Formication

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding the instrument shown below? (INICET MAY 2018) ﻿﻿﻿It is used in women not on thromboprophylaxis and planned for caesarean section. ﻿﻿﻿It is used in women on thromboprophylaxis and planned for caesarean section. ﻿﻿﻿It is removed once the patient starts ambulating.
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) A, B and C

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The image shows a pneumatic compression hose. It is used in women who are not on any thromboprophylaxis and planned for caesarean section. It is also used along with pharmacotherapy in women at risk of thromboembolism undergoing a cesarean section It is discontinued once the patient starts ambulating post-surgery. It is used because pregnancy and surgery increase the risk of thromboembolism.
  • • The image shows a pneumatic compression hose. It is used in women who are not on any thromboprophylaxis and planned for caesarean section.
  • • It is also used along with pharmacotherapy in women at risk of thromboembolism undergoing a cesarean section
  • • It is discontinued once the patient starts ambulating post-surgery.
  • • It is used because pregnancy and surgery increase the risk of thromboembolism.
  • • Different guidelines are there for different societies (Both ACOG and SMFM) recommend pneumatic compression devices for all patients undergoing cesarean section. This table is from Williams and shows the different guidelines:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Pneumatic compression devices are used for thromboembolism prevention in women undergoing cesarean sections, whether or not they are on thromboprophylaxis, and are discontinued once the patient starts ambulating post-surgery.
  • ➤ Ref: Page 2575, Williams Obstetrics 26 th edition
  • ➤ Ref: Page 2575, Williams Obstetrics 26 th edition

questions.text: Which of the following are the classical markers of a seminoma: (INICET NOV 2023) KIT OCT 3 PLAP HCG
questions.explanation: Ans. C) 1, 2 and 3

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true about skeletal muscle contraction? ( INICET May 2020) Extracellular Ca 2+ is important for contraction Ca 2+ is released from mitochondria Ca 2+ is released from the sarcoplasmic reticulum Ligand-gated Ca 2+ channels on sarcolemma have no role in EC coupling
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 3 only

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ During skeletal muscle contraction, Ca2+ is released from the sarcoplasmic reticulum, which is essential for muscle contraction.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is known to be associated with the development of bladder carcinoma? ( NEET PG 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Cyclophosphamide

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Cyclophosphamide is a chemotherapeutic agent used to treat various cancers and autoimmune diseases. One of its known side effects is the increased risk of developing bladder carcinoma. This is due to the metabolite acrolein, which can cause urothelial damage leading to malignancy. Long-term use or high doses of cyclophosphamide significantly elevate this risk.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Cisplatin: Cisplatin is a chemotherapy drug effective against various cancers, including testicular, ovarian, and bladder cancer. However, it is not specifically associated with the development of bladder carcinoma as a side effect.
  • • Option B. Cisplatin:
  • • Option C. Taxane (e.g., paclitaxel, docetaxel): Taxanes are chemotherapeutic agents used in treating breast, ovarian, and lung cancers. They are not linked to bladder carcinoma development.
  • • Option C. Taxane (e.g., paclitaxel, docetaxel):
  • • Option D. Tamoxifen: Tamoxifen is primarily used to treat breast cancer. While it can increase the risk of endometrial cancer due to its estrogen-like effects on uterine tissue, it is not associated with an increased risk of bladder cancer.
  • • Option D. Tamoxifen:
  • • Additional Information on Drugs Associated with Bladder Cancer: Several drugs have been associated with an increased risk of bladder cancer, including:
  • • Additional Information on Drugs Associated with Bladder Cancer:
  • • Pioglitazone : A drug used to treat type 2 diabetes. Aristolochic acid : Found in some herbal remedies. Phenacetin : An analgesic and antipyretic. Aminosalicylates : Used in the treatment of inflammatory bowel disease.
  • • Pioglitazone : A drug used to treat type 2 diabetes.
  • • Pioglitazone
  • • Aristolochic acid : Found in some herbal remedies.
  • • Aristolochic acid
  • • Phenacetin : An analgesic and antipyretic.
  • • Phenacetin
  • • Aminosalicylates : Used in the treatment of inflammatory bowel disease.
  • • Aminosalicylates

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Cyclophosphamide is a chemotherapeutic agent known to be associated with the development of bladder carcinoma due to its metabolite acrolein, which can damage the bladder lining.

questions.text: An anti-arrhythmic drug, which is effective in both atrial and ventricular arrhythmias, is shown to have the following effect on action potential. Which of the following is the most likely drug? ( INICET Nov 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans.  C. Quinidine

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Class IA anti-arrhythmic agents like Quinidine prolong the action potential duration by blocking sodium and potassium channels, making them effective in treating both atrial and ventricular arrhythmias. This effect is clearly reflected in the graph provided, distinguishing it from other classes of anti-arrhythmic drugs.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man presents with abdominal pain, weight loss, and jaundice. Imaging studies reveal a mass arising from the antrum of the stomach extending into the head of the pancreas with metastasis to the right lobe of the liver. What is the appropriate management for this patient? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.correct_answer: A. Palliative gastrojejunostomy followed by chemotherapy
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Palliative gastrojejunostomy followed by chemotherapy

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For patients with advanced gastric cancer extending into adjacent organs and with liver metastasis, the appropriate management often involves palliative measures, such as gastrojejunostomy to relieve symptoms and improve quality of life, followed by chemotherapy. Curative surgical options are generally not feasible in the presence of metastasis.
  • ➤ For patients with advanced gastric cancer extending into adjacent organs and with liver metastasis, the appropriate management often involves palliative measures, such as gastrojejunostomy to relieve symptoms and improve quality of life, followed by chemotherapy.
  • ➤ Curative surgical options are generally not feasible in the presence of metastasis.

questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Never replaced

questions.text: During resuscitation in a patient with severe hypotension and cardiac arrhythmias, a patient received a 20% Intralipid injection. What could have been the most probable diagnosis? ( INICET Nov 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Local anesthesia toxicity

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective :
  • ➤ Intralipid (20% lipid emulsion) is used specifically for treating local anesthetic systemic toxicity (LAST) by acting as a lipid sink to reduce the concentration of the local anesthetic in the plasma.
  • ➤ Ref: Miller’s Anesthesia, 9 th Ed. Pg 885
  • ➤ Ref: Miller’s Anesthesia, 9 th Ed. Pg
  • ➤ 885

questions.text: A patient with 12 weeks amenorrhea presents with vaginal bleeding. On examination, the cervical os is open and the uterus is 14 weeks size. USG shows a snowstorm appearance. The next best step in the management is? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Suction and evacuation

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The snowstorm appearance on ultrasound is characteristic of a complete molar pregnancy (hydatidiform mole). Molar pregnancies are abnormal pregnancies where there is an overgrowth of trophoblastic tissue.
  • • Key Points:
  • • Key Points:
  • • Complete Molar Pregnancy: Presents with vaginal bleeding, an enlarged uterus greater than expected for gestational age, and a snowstorm appearance on ultrasound. Treatment: The primary treatment for a molar pregnancy is suction and evacuation to remove the abnormal trophoblastic tissue. Post-Evacuation Surveillance: After evacuation, it is crucial to monitor beta-hCG levels to ensure complete removal of the molar tissue and to detect any possible malignancy (e.g., choriocarcinoma).
  • • Complete Molar Pregnancy: Presents with vaginal bleeding, an enlarged uterus greater than expected for gestational age, and a snowstorm appearance on ultrasound.
  • • Complete Molar Pregnancy:
  • • Treatment: The primary treatment for a molar pregnancy is suction and evacuation to remove the abnormal trophoblastic tissue.
  • • Treatment:
  • • Post-Evacuation Surveillance: After evacuation, it is crucial to monitor beta-hCG levels to ensure complete removal of the molar tissue and to detect any possible malignancy (e.g., choriocarcinoma).
  • • Post-Evacuation Surveillance:
  • • Other options:
  • • Other options:
  • • Option A. Medical management: Medical management is not appropriate for molar pregnancy, as surgical evacuation is necessary.
  • • Option A. Medical management:
  • • Option B. Follow up with beta-hCG: Beta-hCG monitoring is essential after the initial treatment but not before the evacuation of the molar tissue.
  • • Option B. Follow up with beta-hCG:
  • • Option D. Hysterectomy: Hysterectomy is not the first line of treatment for a molar pregnancy unless there are specific complications or risk factors warranting such an invasive procedure.
  • • Option D. Hysterectomy:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The management of a molar pregnancy involves suction and evacuation to remove the abnormal trophoblastic tissue, followed by post-evacuation surveillance with beta-hCG levels to monitor for persistent gestational trophoblastic disease or malignancy.
  • ➤ Ref: William’s Textbook of obstetrics 26 th edition pg 614
  • ➤ Ref: William’s Textbook of obstetrics 26 th edition pg 614

questions.text: A 5-Month-old neonate is brought to the emergency department with increased irritability, poor feeding, and two episodes of seizures. On examination, the infant appears lethargic with a bulging fontanelle. A lumbar puncture is performed, and the cerebrospinal fluid analysis shows elevated white blood cells, high protein, and low glucose, consistent with bacterial meningitis. What is the most likely causative organism?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Neonatal meningitis is a serious infection commonly caused by specific pathogens due to the neonate’s immature immune system. The most likely causative organism in this clinical scenario is Streptococcus agalactiae (Group B streptococcus) , which is the leading cause of neonatal meningitis and sepsis, particularly in the first few weeks of life. This organism is commonly transmitted from the maternal genital tract during delivery.
  • • Streptococcus agalactiae (Group B streptococcus)
  • • Early vs. Late Onset Meningitis:
  • • Early vs. Late Onset Meningitis:
  • • Early-onset meningitis usually occurs within the first 72 hours of life and is most often caused by Group B streptococcus.
  • • Early-onset meningitis
  • • Late-onset meningitis affects premature infants more commonly and is typically caused by organisms such as coagulase-negative staphylococci, Staphylococcus aureus, Escherichia coli, and Klebsiella.
  • • Late-onset meningitis
  • • Common Causes:
  • • Common Causes:
  • • Group B streptococci are the most frequent cause of neonatal meningitis and sepsis.
  • • Escherichia coli is the most common cause of early-onset sepsis and meningitis among very low birth weight infants (less than 1500 g).
  • • Evaluation and Diagnosis:
  • • Evaluation and Diagnosis:
  • • Neonates are particularly susceptible to infections due to their immature cellular and humoral immunity. Any infant aged 28 days or younger presenting with fever or signs of sepsis should undergo a comprehensive evaluation, including CBC, differential count, blood cultures, urine culture, chest radiograph, and lumbar puncture.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A) Escherichia coli: Commonly causes neonatal meningitis, especially in very low birth weight infants, but Group B streptococcus remains the most frequent in full-term neonates.
  • • Option
  • • A) Escherichia coli:
  • • Option C) Staphylococcus aureus: Typically associated with late-onset infections, particularly in hospitalized infants, but less likely in early-onset neonatal meningitis.
  • • Option
  • • C) Staphylococcus aureus:
  • • Option D) Klebsiella species: Another pathogen that can cause neonatal infections, especially in late-onset cases, but less common than Group B streptococcus in the early neonatal period.
  • • Option
  • • D) Klebsiella species:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Streptococcus agalactiae (Group B streptococcus) is the primary cause of neonatal meningitis and sepsis due to the neonate’s immature immune system. Early identification and appropriate management are crucial to prevent severe complications and improve outcomes in affected infants.

questions.text: Histology of reperfused myocardium is suggestive of which of the following features? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Eosinophilic contraction band

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Eosinophilic contraction bands are a characteristic histological feature of reperfused myocardium, indicating irreversible injury and exaggerated myofibril contraction due to high intracellular calcium levels upon restoration of blood flow.

questions.text: During fetal autopsy, what is the order of examination to differentiate between live and stillbirth ? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Head > Abdomen > Thorax

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ During a fetal autopsy, the correct sequence of examination is Head > Abdomen > Thorax, with the abdomen being opened before the thorax to check the diaphragm level for respiration evidence
